title: Kenyan Athletics Championships
text:
The Kenyan Athletics Championships is an annual <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> meeting which serves as <a href="Kenya">Kenya</a>'s <a href="national%20championships">national championships</a> for the sport. <a href="Athletics%20Kenya">Athletics Kenya</a>, the country's governing body for <a href="sport%20of%20athletics">athletics</a> organises the event.
The championships is usually held over a three-day period and the location varies, though the capital <a href="Nairobi">Nairobi</a> is a frequent choice as it has both <a href="Nyayo%20National%20Stadium">Nyayo National Stadium</a> and the <a href="Moi%20International%20Sports%20Centre">Moi International Sports Centre</a>. The national championships may also serve as the trials for selection to the national team for competitions such as the <a href="IAAF%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">IAAF World Championships in Athletics</a>, <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Olympic Games</a>, <a href="African%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">African Championships in Athletics</a> and the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%20African%20Games">Africa Games</a>.
On some occasions the trial events are held separately from the main national championships. As a result of this, the national championships can be less of a focus for Kenyan athletes and lesser performances are produced, with slow tactical races common in the <a href="long-distance%20running">long-distance track events</a>. Athletics Kenya mitigates this by offering cash bonuses for national champions.
The championships was well established by the 1980s, hosting a full range of Olympic-level individual track events for men. By 1981, the women's programme featured track races from <a href="100%20metres">100 metres</a> to <a href="3000%20metres">3000 metres</a>, two hurdles events, <a href="high%20jump">high jump</a>, <a href="long%20jump">long jump</a>, three throws (<a href="shot%20put">shot put</a>, <a href="discus%20throw">discus</a>, <a href="javelin%20throw">javelin</a>), <a href="heptathlon">heptathlon</a> and a <a href="20%2C000%20metres%20track%20walk">20,000 metres track walk</a>. A <a href="10%2C000%20metres">10,000 metres</a> was introduced in 1987, a <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a> following in 1991, then the <a href="steeplechase%20%28athletics%29">steeplechase</a> and <a href="hammer%20throw">hammer throw</a> came in 1998. The addition of the women's <a href="pole%20vault">pole vault</a> in 1999 marked parity of events between the sexes at the Kenyan Championships.
